Why Text Structure Matters Properly formatted text: Improves readability for users Helps search engines understand your content Creates visual hierarchy on your page Core HTML Text Elements 1. Headings (

to

per page (for SEO) Maintain logical heading order (don't skip levels) 2. Paragraphs (

entry.title: ArkTS programming specification(3)
entry.summary:
Spacing and Code Style Guidelines
Highlighting Keywords and Important Information with Spaces
Level: Recommendation Description: Use spaces to highlight keywords and important information while avoiding unnecessary spaces. Follow these general guidelines: Add a space between keywords like if, for, while, switch and the left parenthesis (. Do not add a space between the function name and the left parenthesis ( in function definitions and calls. Add a space between keywords like else or catch and the preceding right brace }. Add a space before any opening brace {, except in the following cases:
When an object is the first parameter of a function or the first element of an array, no space is needed before the object. For example: foo({ name: 'abc' }). In templates, no space i‚Ä¶

In this blog post, we‚Äôll cover how to connect to an exchange, get‚Ä¶ This blog post is part of a series on building a simple trading bot. In this blog post, we‚Äôll cover how to connect to an exchange, get price data, and use a trading indicator to interpret that data. The next blog post will focus on adding a notification system, followed by a guide on executing trades based on the trading indicator. There are many forms of trading, each presenting unique opportunities and challenges. One question can be ‚ÄúWhat to trade?‚Äù. Here we have, for example, equities, commodities, currencies and crypto currencies. Then we may ask ‚ÄúHow frequently?‚Äù and come out with scalping, day-trading, swing trading, positional trading. Another deci‚Ä¶

entry.title: ArkTS programming specification(2)
ArkTS programming specification(1)
entry.summary:
Coding Guidelines for ArkTS
Target and Applicability
This document, aligned with industry standards and practices and tailored to the features of ArkTS, offers coding guidelines to enhance code standardization, security, and performance. It is designed for developers engaged in system or application development using ArkTS. ArkTS builds on the basic syntax of TypeScript and introduces enhanced static checking and analysis. Some rules in this guide are adapted from the "OpenHarmony Application TS&JS Programming Guide", with additions specific to ArkTS to boost code readability and performance. Code Style: Covers naming and formatting. Programming Practices: Includes declarations, initializations, data types, operations, expressions, and exceptions. The rules are refined based o‚Ä¶

entry.title: üì¶ Cardboard.js: Building a Simpler, More Intuitive Framework
entry.summary:
Hey there! Hope you're having an amazing week! üöÄ If you're new here, let me introduce you to Cardboard.js‚Äîa lightweight, reactive web framework that lets you build dynamic web apps with just JavaScript or TypeScript. No HTML templates, no unnecessary boilerplate‚Äîjust clean, reactive code. Curious? Check out the repository to dive right in! This post is a devlog and changelog about the latest updates to Cardboard.js. It‚Äôs all about making the framework more intuitive, developer-friendly, and powerful. Let‚Äôs dive into what‚Äôs new and why it matters! Making Names Make Sense
One of the biggest challenges in any framework is naming things. Names should be intuitive, descriptive, and align with industry standards. In this update, I focused on renaming key concepts in Cardboard.js to make them ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Use Code Generation To Advance Your Career
entry.summary:
Opening Story
This post will detail one example of how I have used code generation to advance my career. While working for a large government contractor the team was looking for a software solution for tracking server configurations. We wanted to know what applications were installed on the servers and what versions of the applications were installed. We also wanted information on some applications that were xcopy deployed on the servers. We also needed information about the patches installed on Oracle instances. After listening to a vendor's presentation about their solution to our problem on a Friday afternoon I realized that I could build a 90% solution over the weekend. I started with a database schema to hold the data I needed to produce the reports that are required. I wrote a .Net‚Ä¶

entry.title: AI-Powered Infrastructure as Code: Revolutionizing Cloud Management
entry.summary: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) has fundamentally shifted how organizations provision and manage their IT environments, bringing automation, versioning, and repeatability to a once manual and error-prone domain. However, as cloud environments grow in complexity and scale, the cognitive load of writing, maintaining, and optimizing IaC can become a significant bottleneck. Enter the transformative power of Artificial Intelligence (AI), particularly Large Language Models (LLMs) and Machine Learning (ML), which are poised to revolutionize IaC by introducing new levels of intelligence, automation, and efficiency. One of the most immediate and impactful applications of AI in IaC is the ability of LLMs to generate infrastructure code from natural language prompts. Imagine describing your desired infr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Zigzag Level Order Traversal in Java: A Simple and Clear Guide
entry.summary:
Zigzag Level Order Traversal in Java: A Simple and Clear Guide
Working with binary trees can be exciting, especially when you encounter traversal problems that require a little twist.
One such problem is Zigzag Level Order Traversal, where you don‚Äôt simply traverse each level from left to right‚Äîyou need to alternate directions on each level. In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through the solution using Java, provide step-by-step explanations, and share some helpful insights to make the concept stick. The task is to traverse a binary tree level by level, but the direction switches at each level. First level: left to right Second level: right to left Third level: left to right And so on‚Ä¶ This creates a zigzag or spiral-like pattern. Given the following tree: 1 / \ 2 3 ‚Ä¶

entry.title: No-Code OSS Use Cases: Common Questions Answered
entry.summary: No-code OSS use cases enable telecom operations to build, test, and deploy workflows through a visual interface‚Äîno scripting required. By dragging pre-built connectors onto a canvas, teams can automate tasks like service provisioning, alarm handling, and firmware rollouts in hours instead of weeks. This Q&A guide explains what no-code OSS use cases are, why they matter, and how to identify your first high-impact workflow. A no-code OSS use case is any operational scenario, such as provisioning broadband, managing alarms, or rolling out firmware, configured entirely through a drag-and-drop interface. Instead of writing scripts, you pick from pre-built connectors (CRM, inventory, NMS/EMS) and draw the logic on a canvas. The platform generates all API calls and business rules automatically. S‚Ä¶

entry.title: Storing AWR Snapshots Outside SYSAUX
entry.summary: As you know, AWR snapshots are stored in the SYSAUX tablespace by default, and until version 19c, it was not possible to store them in a separate tablespace. This capability was introduced in version 19c with the addition of the TABLESPACE_NAME parameter to the procedure dbms_workload_repository.modify_snapshot_settings. Details of the modify_snapshot_settings procedure in 19c: Connected to Oracle Database 19c Enterprise Edition Release 19.0.0.0.0 SQL> desc dbms_workload_repository.modify_snapshot_settings Parameter Type Mode Default? --------------- -------- ---- -------- RETENTION NUMBER IN Y INTERVAL NUMBER IN Y TOPNSQL NUMBER IN Y DBID NUMBER IN Y TABLESPACE_NAME VARCHAR2 IN Y RETENTI‚Ä¶
